1592 2 Novem
b
To the LLs of the Councell
May it please yo
r
good LL. for that whiche
is required by yo
r
LL letter of
e 17 of Oc
t
.
w
ch
I receaved
e 31 enjoining
e dispatche of
S
r
Nicholas Parkers
horsband, I have advertised
at large what impediments I founde: w
ch
I
hope are already imparted to yo
r
LL if my
letter therupon, w
ch
I addressed of late unto my
L. Treasurer
, be safely delivered. S
r
Nicholas
Parker hath bin ready, as muche as lay in him,
sins
e time
at
e army of
e states was dissolved.
But by reason I had no order, for
e place of his
Rendevous, I was forced to forbeare from urging
his departure. For to embarke all his horses,
and to attend a winde in
Zeland
, w
t
e companies
of foote, considering
e uncertaintie of getting
shipping for [
Jeresey
], it was thought it would
prove
e overthrowe of his troupe. Moreover
though
e states have bin solicited to graunt him
a pasport, to remove from
Duisbourgh
to
Berghen
,
where
S
r
John Poley
is in garrison, to have the
better commoditie for supplie of his companie,
they doe not onely refuse to admitte him into
Berghen, but they will give him no pasport
for any other place. Whether they thinke by
that meanes, to stay him heere for all together, or
to lette him from diminishing S
r
John Poleis
cornet, I can not certifie for certaine. But
assoone as I have notice of
e place of
e Rendevous,
I will take as good a course, as is possible for me,
to procure him a passage: and w
t
all I will
fol.352v
use what meanes I am able, to cause S
r
John Poley
to convey some horses unto him. I am sure it
will prove a troublesome attempt, if the states
be unwilling: but except they doe resist in
violent sort, w
ch
I thinke they will not doe, I
hope I shall effect it. S
r
Nicholas Parker
himself I have found very forward to doe any
thing required: and although it be apparant,
that by this last sommers service many of his
souldiers are unmounted, and divers of his hors
e
dead
hurt
and decaied, whereby his numbers are
abated, yet I take his band, as it is, to be the
best in order, and
e most sufficient in this
contrey. He maketh no doubt of persuading
divers of his souldiers, w
ch
are of this contrey,
and men of good worth, to folowe him in this
voiage: and suche as shall refuse, for
at they
are maried, or for other respectes, he will
passe them in exchange w
t
S
r
John Poley and other
captaines, so as al waies
her Ma
tie
shall be served
of his troupe in very good strength. Wherein
my best endevo
r
shall appeere unto yo
r
LL
and so I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage N
o.
2 1592.
Yo
r
LL most humbl
e
at commaundement Tho. Bodl
